1.General: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh's officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
1.Non-Denominational: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh's officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
1.Baptist: The narrative returns to Joseph, reiterating his arrival in Egypt as a slave. He is purchased by Potiphar, identified as an Egyptian, an officer of Pharaoh, and captain of the guard, from the Ishmaelites/Midianites who brought him there.
1.Catholic: The narrative resumes Joseph's story, specifying his arrival in Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian official of Pharaoh holding the position of captain of the guard, purchases Joseph from the Ishmaelites who transported him there.
1.Methodist: The story returns to Joseph in Egypt. Potiphar (Pharaoh's official, captain of the guard) buys Joseph from the Ishmaelites.
1.Lutheran: Joseph was brought down to Egypt. Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the Ishmaelites who brought him down there.
1.Presbyterian: Resuming Joseph's story, he is bought in Egypt by Potiphar (Pharaoh's captain of the guard) from the Ishmaelite traders.
1.Pentecostal: Joseph taken to Egypt, bought by Potiphar (Pharaoh's official, captain of guard) from Ishmaelites.
1.Episcopalian/Anglican: The narrative returns to Joseph, now in Egypt, purchased by Potiphar (an Egyptian official, Pharaoh's captain of the guard) from the Ishmaelites.
1.Orthodox: The story refocuses on Joseph in Egypt. He is acquired by Potiphar, an Egyptian official serving Pharaoh as captain of the guard, from the Ishmaelite merchants.
1.Other: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh's officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
1.Prefer not to say: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt. Potiphar, an Egyptian who was one of Pharaoh's officials, the captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.

2.General: The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
2.Non-Denominational: The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
2.Baptist: A key theological statement: despite Joseph's circumstances as a slave, 'the LORD was with Joseph.' This divine presence leads to Joseph's success and prosperity, even within Potiphar's household.
2.Catholic: Crucially, the text states 'The LORD was with Joseph,' attributing his subsequent success and prosperity directly to God's favor, even while serving as a slave in Potiphar's house.
2.Methodist: Emphasizes God's presence with Joseph ('The Lord was with Joseph'), resulting in his success and prosperity while living in Potiphar's house.
2.Lutheran: The Lord was with Joseph, and he became a successful man. He was in the house of his Egyptian master.
2.Presbyterian: Highlights God's covenant faithfulness: the Lord remained with Joseph, enabling him to prosper even in slavery within Potiphar's household.
2.Pentecostal: God's presence brings favor and success to Joseph, even in slavery.
2.Episcopalian/Anglican: States clearly that 'the Lord was with Joseph,' leading to his prosperity within the household of his Egyptian master, Potiphar.
2.Orthodox: A pivotal assertion: 'The LORD was with Joseph.' This divine companionship is presented as the source of Joseph's prosperity and success within Potiphar's household.
2.Other: The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
2.Prefer not to say: The Lord was with Joseph so that he prospered, and he lived in the house of his Egyptian master.

3.General: When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,
3.Non-Denominational: When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,
3.Baptist: Potiphar observes Joseph's consistent success and recognizes that it stems from the Lord's blessing upon him ('saw that the LORD was with him and that the LORD caused all that he did to succeed').
3.Catholic: Potiphar, Joseph's master, perceives both that the LORD is with Joseph and that the LORD is the source of Joseph's remarkable success in all his undertakings.
3.Methodist: Potiphar notices that the Lord is with Joseph and gives him success in his work.
3.Lutheran: His master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord caused all that he did to succeed in his hands.
3.Presbyterian: Potiphar observes Joseph's effectiveness and attributes it to the Lord's presence and blessing upon Joseph's work.
3.Pentecostal: Potiphar recognizes God's favor on Joseph brings success to everything Joseph does.
3.Episcopalian/Anglican: Potiphar observes that the Lord is with Joseph and is the reason for Joseph's success in all tasks.
3.Orthodox: Potiphar discerns the divine presence accompanying Joseph and recognizes it as the origin of his consistent success in all endeavors.
3.Other: When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,
3.Prefer not to say: When his master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord gave him success in everything he did,

4.General: Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.
4.Non-Denominational: Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.
4.Baptist: Because of God's blessing and Joseph's competence, Joseph finds favor with Potiphar. He is promoted from a general slave to Potiphar's personal attendant and eventually appointed as overseer of Potiphar's entire household and all his possessions.
4.Catholic: As a result of God's evident blessing, Joseph gains Potiphar's favor. Potiphar appoints him as his personal servant and then elevates him to supervisor ('overseer') of his entire household, entrusting all his property and affairs to Joseph's management.
4.Methodist: Joseph gains Potiphar's favor and is promoted to personal attendant, then overseer of the entire household, entrusted with all Potiphar owns.
4.Lutheran: Joseph finds favor in his sight and attended him. Potiphar made him overseer of his house and put him in charge of all that he had.
4.Presbyterian: Joseph gains Potiphar's favor and trust, leading to his promotion as overseer of the entire household and all its affairs.
4.Pentecostal: Joseph finds favor, becomes attendant, then Potiphar puts him in charge of everything.
4.Episcopalian/Anglican: Joseph finds favor with Potiphar, becoming his personal attendant and then being appointed overseer of the entire household, entrusted with all possessions.
4.Orthodox: Consequently, Joseph obtains Potiphar's favor and is appointed as his personal attendant. Subsequently, Potiphar elevates him to supervisor of his household, conferring upon him responsibility for all his possessions.
4.Other: Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.
4.Prefer not to say: Joseph found favor in his eyes and became his attendant. Potiphar put him in charge of his household, and he entrusted to his care everything he owned.

5.General: From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.
5.Non-Denominational: From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.
5.Baptist: The blessing of God extends beyond Joseph himself. Because of Joseph and his faithful service, God blesses Potiphar's entire household and all his affairs, both domestic ('house') and agricultural/business ('field').
5.Catholic: Once Joseph is appointed overseer, the LORD's blessing extends to Potiphar's household and possessions explicitly 'for Joseph's sake.' This divine favor benefits everything Potiphar owns, encompassing both his domestic affairs and his agricultural interests.
5.Methodist: Because of Joseph's appointment, the Lord blesses Potiphar's household for Joseph's sake. The blessing covers everything, indoors and outdoors.
5.Lutheran: From the time Potiphar made him overseer, the Lord blessed the Egyptian's house for Joseph's sake. The Lord's blessing was on all that he had, in house and field.
5.Presbyterian: God blesses Potiphar's household and affairs as a result of Joseph's presence and stewardship, demonstrating blessing extending through God's servant.
5.Pentecostal: God blesses Potiphar's house and field because of Joseph being put in charge.
5.Episcopalian/Anglican: From the time Joseph was put in charge, the Lord blesses Potiphar's household for Joseph's sake, covering everything in the house and fields.
5.Orthodox: Following Joseph's appointment, the LORD blesses Potiphar's household specifically on account of Joseph. This blessing encompasses all of Potiphar's assets, both domestic and agricultural.
5.Other: From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.
5.Prefer not to say: From the time he put him in charge of his household and of all that he owned, the Lord blessed the household of the Egyptian because of Joseph. The blessing of the Lord was on everything Potiphar had, both in the house and in the field.

6.General: So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph's care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,
6.Non-Denominational: So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph's care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,
6.Baptist: Potiphar develops complete trust in Joseph, delegating full responsibility for all his affairs, only concerning himself with his personal meals. The narrative then adds a physical description of Joseph: he was handsome in form and appearance, setting the stage for the next event.
6.Catholic: Potiphar's trust in Joseph becomes absolute; he entrusts everything to Joseph's management, paying attention only to his own meals. The text then transitions by noting Joseph's physical attractiveness: he was 'handsome in form and appearance.'
6.Methodist: Potiphar trusts Joseph completely, leaving everything in his care except his own food. The verse adds that Joseph was physically attractive.
6.Lutheran: He left all that he had in Joseph's charge. Because of him, he had no concern about anything but the food he ate. Now Joseph was handsome in form and appearance.
6.Presbyterian: Potiphar delegates complete authority to Joseph, trusting him implicitly. The narrative notes Joseph's handsome appearance, foreshadowing temptation.
6.Pentecostal: Potiphar trusts Joseph with everything except food. Joseph was handsome.
6.Episcopalian/Anglican: Potiphar entrusts everything to Joseph, concerning himself only with his food. The narrative notes Joseph was well-built and handsome.
6.Orthodox: Potiphar delegates complete oversight to Joseph, concerning himself solely with personal matters like his meals. The text then introduces Joseph's physical attractiveness as a significant detail.
6.Other: So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph's care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,
6.Prefer not to say: So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph's care; with Joseph in charge, he did not concern himself with anything except the food he ate. Now Joseph was well-built and handsome,

7.General: and after a while his master's wife took notice of Joseph and said, "Come to bed with me!"
7.Non-Denominational: and after a while his master's wife took notice of Joseph and said, "Come to bed with me!"
7.Baptist: Joseph's handsome appearance attracts the attention of Potiphar's wife. After some time, she directly propositions Joseph, inviting him to commit adultery with her.
7.Catholic: Following the mention of Joseph's appearance, Potiphar's wife begins to desire him ('cast her eyes on Joseph') and explicitly propositions him for sexual relations: 'Lie with me.'
7.Methodist: Potiphar's wife notices Joseph's attractiveness and propositions him.
7.Lutheran: After a time, his master's wife cast her eyes on Joseph and said, 'Lie with me.'
7.Presbyterian: Potiphar's wife notices Joseph's appearance and attempts to seduce him, inviting him to commit adultery.
7.Pentecostal: Potiphar's wife notices Joseph, tells him to sleep with her.
7.Episcopalian/Anglican: After some time, Potiphar's wife takes notice of Joseph and propositions him sexually.
7.Orthodox: Subsequently, Potiphar's wife develops an attraction to Joseph and directly invites him to engage in illicit sexual relations with her.
7.Other: and after a while his master's wife took notice of Joseph and said, "Come to bed with me!"
7.Prefer not to say: and after a while his master's wife took notice of Joseph and said, "Come to bed with me!"

8.General: But he refused. "With me in charge," he told her, "my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.
8.Non-Denominational: But he refused. "With me in charge," he told her, "my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.
8.Baptist: Joseph immediately refuses her advance. He first appeals to his loyalty to Potiphar, emphasizing the immense trust and responsibility his master has placed in him over the entire household.
8.Catholic: Joseph firmly refuses her proposal. He begins his reasoning by highlighting his position of trust and responsibility within the household, stressing that Potiphar has entrusted everything to him.
8.Methodist: Joseph refuses, first citing his loyalty to Potiphar and the great trust placed in him over the household.
8.Lutheran: He refused and told his master's wife that his master had no concern about anything in the house, having put everything in his charge.
8.Presbyterian: Joseph refuses, appealing first to his duty and loyalty towards Potiphar, who has entrusted him with everything.
8.Pentecostal: Joseph refuses, explains Potiphar trusts him with everything in the house.
8.Episcopalian/Anglican: Joseph refuses, explaining the immense trust Potiphar has placed in him, putting him in charge of the entire household.
8.Orthodox: Joseph resolutely declines her invitation. He initially appeals to his fidelity to Potiphar, emphasizing the comprehensive authority and trust vested in him over the household affairs.
8.Other: But he refused. "With me in charge," he told her, "my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.
8.Prefer not to say: But he refused. "With me in charge," he told her, "my master does not concern himself with anything in the house; everything he owns he has entrusted to my care.

9.General: No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"
9.Non-Denominational: No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"
9.Baptist: Joseph continues his refusal, stating Potiphar has withheld nothing from him except his wife. He then frames the act primarily as a sin against God: 'How then can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God?' This demonstrates his commitment to God's moral standard above all else.
9.Catholic: Joseph further emphasizes his authority ('no one is greater in this house than I') and that Potiphar has restricted access only to his wife. He culminates his refusal by identifying the proposed act not only as a betrayal of Potiphar but fundamentally as a grave offense against God: 'How then can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God?'
9.Methodist: Joseph states Potiphar has withheld nothing except her (his wife). He concludes that betraying this trust would be a great wickedness and, crucially, a sin against God.
9.Lutheran: He says he is not greater in the house than his master, who has kept nothing back from him except her, because she is his wife. He asks how he could do this great wickedness and sin against God.
9.Presbyterian: Joseph argues that betraying Potiphar's trust by sleeping with his wife would be a profound wickedness and, most importantly, a direct sin against God.
9.Pentecostal: Joseph says Potiphar withheld nothing but her (his wife). Asks how he could do such wickedness and sin against God.
9.Episcopalian/Anglican: Joseph explains Potiphar has withheld nothing from him except his wife, and concludes by asking how he could commit such great wickedness and sin against God.
9.Orthodox: Joseph asserts his significant authority within the household, noting that only Potiphar's wife is withheld from him. He emphatically frames the proposed adultery as a profound transgression primarily against God.
9.Other: No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"
9.Prefer not to say: No one is greater in this house than I am. My master has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"

10.General: And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
10.Non-Denominational: And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
10.Baptist: Potiphar's wife persists in her advances ('day after day'). Joseph consistently refuses not only to sleep with her but also avoids being alone with her or in her company, demonstrating proactive measures to avoid temptation.
10.Catholic: Despite her persistent daily enticements, Joseph steadfastly refuses ('did not listen to her') either to lie with her or even to be in her presence unnecessarily, actively avoiding the compromising situation.
10.Methodist: She persists daily, but Joseph consistently refuses to sleep with her or even spend unnecessary time with her.
10.Lutheran: She spoke to Joseph day after day, but he would not listen to her, to lie beside her or to be with her.
10.Presbyterian: Joseph consistently resists her repeated advances, refusing to yield to temptation and actively avoiding her company.
10.Pentecostal: She persists daily, but Joseph refuses to sleep with her or even be near her.
10.Episcopalian/Anglican: Despite her daily persistence, Joseph continually refuses to sleep with her or even to be alone with her.
10.Orthodox: Notwithstanding her persistent daily solicitations, Joseph consistently declines to engage in intimacy with her or even to remain in her proximity, actively distancing himself from the temptation.
10.Other: And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.
10.Prefer not to say: And though she spoke to Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or even be with her.

11.General: One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.
11.Non-Denominational: One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.
11.Baptist: An opportune moment for Potiphar's wife arises: Joseph enters the house to perform his work, and finds that none of the other male servants are present inside.
11.Catholic: An occasion arises when Joseph enters the house to carry out his responsibilities, and significantly, none of the other household servants are present indoors.
11.Methodist: Sets the scene for the climax: Joseph goes inside to work, and finds none of the other servants are there.
11.Lutheran: One day, he went into the house to do his work, and none of the men of the house were there inside.
11.Presbyterian: A specific day presents an opportunity for Potiphar's wife: Joseph is inside attending to duties, and no other servants are present.
11.Pentecostal: Opportunity arises: Joseph goes inside to work, no other servants are there.
11.Episcopalian/Anglican: One day, Joseph goes into the house to do his work, and finds none of the other household servants inside.
11.Orthodox: A particular day presents an opportunity: Joseph enters the house for his duties when none of the other male servants are within.
11.Other: One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.
11.Prefer not to say: One day he went into the house to attend to his duties, and none of the household servants was inside.

12.General: She caught him by his cloak and said, "Come to bed with me!" But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.
12.Non-Denominational: She caught him by his cloak and said, "Come to bed with me!" But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.
12.Baptist: Seizing the opportunity, she physically grabs Joseph by his outer garment (cloak) and repeats her demand. Joseph chooses immediate flight over resistance or argument, leaving his cloak behind in her grasp as he runs out of the house.
12.Catholic: She grabs Joseph by his garment, repeating her proposition, 'Lie with me.' Prioritizing escape from sin over his garment (and potentially his reputation), Joseph flees the house, leaving the cloak in her hand.
12.Methodist: She grabs his cloak and demands he sleep with her. Joseph flees immediately, leaving the cloak behind.
12.Lutheran: She caught him by his garment, saying, 'Lie with me.' But he left his garment in her hand and fled and got out of the house.
12.Presbyterian: She physically detains him by his cloak, demanding compliance. Joseph escapes by leaving his cloak behind and running outside.
12.Pentecostal: She grabs his cloak, demands sex. He leaves cloak, runs out.
12.Episcopalian/Anglican: She catches Joseph by his cloak, demanding he lie with her. He leaves the cloak in her hand and flees the house.
12.Orthodox: She physically restrains Joseph by his garment, reiterating her demand. Joseph prioritizes escaping the sinful situation, abandoning his cloak in her hand and fleeing the house.
12.Other: She caught him by his cloak and said, "Come to bed with me!" But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.
12.Prefer not to say: She caught him by his cloak and said, "Come to bed with me!" But he left his cloak in her hand and ran out of the house.

13.General: When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
13.Non-Denominational: When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
13.Baptist: Potiphar's wife is left holding Joseph's cloak after he fled.
13.Catholic: She observes that Joseph has fled, leaving his garment in her possession.
13.Methodist: She sees Joseph has fled, leaving his cloak with her.
13.Lutheran: When she saw that he had left his garment in her hand and fled out of the house,
13.Presbyterian: Realizing Joseph has escaped and left his cloak, she prepares her false accusation.
13.Pentecostal: She sees he left cloak and ran out.
13.Episcopalian/Anglican: She sees that Joseph has fled, leaving his cloak in her hand.
13.Orthodox: Observing Joseph's flight and the cloak remaining in her grasp, she formulates her deceptive account.
13.Other: When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,
13.Prefer not to say: When she saw that he had left his cloak in her hand and had run out of the house,

14.General: she called her household servants. "Look," she said to them, "this Hebrew has been brought to us to insult us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
14.Non-Denominational: she called her household servants. "Look," she said to them, "this Hebrew has been brought to us to insult us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
14.Baptist: She immediately calls the other servants and begins her false accusation. She uses ethnic prejudice ('this Hebrew') and claims Joseph was brought in to 'mock' or 'insult' them. She lies, stating Joseph came in to assault her, but she screamed loudly.
14.Catholic: She summons the household servants and presents her fabricated story. She refers to Joseph disparagingly as 'this Hebrew,' accusing Potiphar of bringing him in to 'mock' or 'insult' them. She falsely claims Joseph entered intending to violate her, but her loud scream deterred him.
14.Methodist: She calls the servants and lies: accuses Potiphar of bringing 'this Hebrew' to insult them, claims Joseph tried to assault her, but she screamed.
14.Lutheran: She called to the men of her household and said, 'See, he has brought among us a Hebrew to laugh at us. He came in to lie with me, and I cried out with a loud voice.'
14.Presbyterian: She summons the servants and falsely accuses Joseph, using prejudice ('this Hebrew') and claiming he assaulted her until she screamed.
14.Pentecostal: She calls servants, blames Potiphar for bringing 'this Hebrew' to mock them, lies that Joseph tried to sleep with her but she screamed.
14.Episcopalian/Anglican: She calls the household servants and begins her false accusation, blaming Potiphar for bringing 'this Hebrew' to insult them and claiming Joseph came to lie with her, but she screamed.
14.Orthodox: She summons the household staff and constructs her false narrative, employing ethnic bias ('this Hebrew') and accusing Joseph of attempting to assault her, claiming her screams thwarted him.
14.Other: she called her household servants. "Look," she said to them, "this Hebrew has been brought to us to insult us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.
14.Prefer not to say: she called her household servants. "Look," she said to them, "this Hebrew has been brought to us to insult us! He came in here to sleep with me, but I screamed.

15.General: When he heard me scream, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
15.Non-Denominational: When he heard me scream, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
15.Baptist: She continues the lie, claiming Joseph fled, leaving his cloak, only because he heard her screaming.
15.Catholic: She further embellishes her lie, asserting that Joseph abandoned his garment and fled solely because he heard her loud cry.
15.Methodist: She claims Joseph fled and left his cloak only because she screamed.
15.Lutheran: 'As soon as he heard that I lifted up my voice and cried out, he left his garment beside me and fled and got out of the house.'
15.Presbyterian: She falsely claims Joseph fled and left his cloak only when she screamed for help.
15.Pentecostal: Claims he left cloak and ran only when she screamed.
15.Episcopalian/Anglican: She claims Joseph left his cloak and fled only when he heard her scream.
15.Orthodox: She falsely attributes Joseph's flight and abandonment of his cloak to her alleged screams.
15.Other: When he heard me scream, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
15.Prefer not to say: When he heard me scream, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."

16.General: She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
16.Non-Denominational: She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
16.Baptist: She holds onto the cloak as physical 'evidence' to present to Potiphar upon his return.
16.Catholic: She retains Joseph's garment as supposed evidence until Potiphar returns home.
16.Methodist: She keeps the cloak as false evidence until Potiphar gets home.
16.Lutheran: She laid up his garment by her until his master came home.
16.Presbyterian: She keeps the cloak as fabricated evidence to show Potiphar.
16.Pentecostal: She keeps the cloak as evidence until Potiphar returns.
16.Episcopalian/Anglican: She keeps Joseph's cloak with her as evidence until Potiphar returns home.
16.Orthodox: She preserves the cloak as fabricated proof to present upon Potiphar's return.
16.Other: She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.
16.Prefer not to say: She kept his cloak beside her until his master came home.

17.General: Then she told him this story: "That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to insult me.
17.Non-Denominational: Then she told him this story: "That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to insult me.
17.Baptist: When Potiphar returns, she repeats her false accusation, again using the prejudicial term 'Hebrew slave' and framing Joseph's alleged actions as an insult facilitated by Potiphar himself.
17.Catholic: Upon Potiphar's return, she recounts her fabricated story, again using the derogatory phrase 'Hebrew servant' and implying Potiphar was complicit by bringing Joseph into the house ('whom you brought among us'), claiming Joseph intended to 'mock' or insult her.
17.Methodist: She repeats the false story to Potiphar, again blaming him indirectly ('that Hebrew slave you brought us') and claiming Joseph came to insult her.
17.Lutheran: She told him the same story, saying, 'The Hebrew servant, whom you have brought among us, came in to me to laugh at me.'
17.Presbyterian: She repeats her false accusation to Potiphar, again using prejudice and blaming Joseph for intending to insult her.
17.Pentecostal: She tells Potiphar the lie: 'Hebrew slave you brought us' came to insult her.
17.Episcopalian/Anglican: She tells Potiphar her false story, blaming the 'Hebrew slave' whom Potiphar brought into the house for coming to insult her.
17.Orthodox: When Potiphar arrives, she presents her concocted narrative, again using ethnic disparagement ('Hebrew slave') and claiming Joseph sought to dishonor her.
17.Other: Then she told him this story: "That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to insult me.
17.Prefer not to say: Then she told him this story: "That Hebrew slave you brought us came to me to insult me.

18.General: But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
18.Non-Denominational: But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
18.Baptist: She concludes her lie to Potiphar, claiming Joseph fled only when she screamed, leaving the cloak as proof.
18.Catholic: She concludes her accusation to Potiphar by claiming Joseph fled and left his garment only when she cried out loudly.
18.Methodist: She finishes her lie, stating Joseph fled and left the cloak only when she screamed.
18.Lutheran: 'But as soon as I lifted up my voice and cried out, he left his garment beside me and fled out of the house.'
18.Presbyterian: She finishes her false account, claiming her screams caused Joseph to flee, leaving the cloak.
18.Pentecostal: Claims again he fled and left cloak only when she screamed.
18.Episcopalian/Anglican: She repeats the claim that Joseph fled and left his cloak only when she screamed.
18.Orthodox: She concludes her false report to Potiphar by asserting that Joseph's flight and the abandonment of his cloak were direct results of her outcry.
18.Other: But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."
18.Prefer not to say: But as soon as I screamed for help, he left his cloak beside me and ran out of the house."

19.General: When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, "This is how your slave treated me," he burned with anger.
19.Non-Denominational: When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, "This is how your slave treated me," he burned with anger.
19.Baptist: Potiphar hears his wife's account and becomes furious. His anger is kindled by the perceived betrayal and assault by his trusted servant.
19.Catholic: Upon hearing his wife's accusatory words ('These are the things your servant did to me'), Potiphar becomes enraged ('his anger was kindled').
19.Methodist: Potiphar hears his wife's false story and becomes very angry.
19.Lutheran: As soon as his master heard the words that his wife spoke to him, saying, 'This is the way your servant treated me,' his anger was kindled.
19.Presbyterian: Potiphar believes his wife's false accusation and becomes intensely angry at Joseph.
19.Pentecostal: Potiphar hears wife's story, believes it, gets very angry.
19.Episcopalian/Anglican: When Potiphar hears his wife's story about how Joseph allegedly treated her, he becomes enraged.
19.Orthodox: Hearing his wife's fabricated account, Potiphar is consumed with anger at the perceived violation by Joseph.
19.Other: When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, "This is how your slave treated me," he burned with anger.
19.Prefer not to say: When his master heard the story his wife told him, saying, "This is how your slave treated me," he burned with anger.

20.General: Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined.
20.Non-Denominational: Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined.
20.Baptist: Potiphar, in his anger, has Joseph imprisoned. The specific prison is noted as the one where prisoners of the state or king were held, suggesting a high-security or official prison, perhaps connected to Potiphar's role as captain of the guard.
20.Catholic: Acting on his anger, Potiphar has Joseph arrested and incarcerated in the specific prison designated for holding the king's prisoners.
20.Methodist: Potiphar throws Joseph into prison – specifically, the prison where the king's prisoners were kept.
20.Lutheran: Joseph's master took him and put him into the prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined, and he was there in prison.
20.Presbyterian: Potiphar imprisons Joseph in the facility used for royal prisoners, possibly reflecting Potiphar's official position.
20.Pentecostal: Potiphar puts Joseph in the prison where king's prisoners were kept.
20.Episcopalian/Anglican: Potiphar takes Joseph and puts him into the prison where the king's prisoners were confined.
20.Orthodox: Potiphar consigns Joseph to the prison specifically used for incarcerating prisoners associated with the king or state affairs.
20.Other: Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined.
20.Prefer not to say: Joseph's master took him and put him in prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined.

21.General: But while Joseph was there in the prison, the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
21.Non-Denominational: But while Joseph was there in the prison, the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
21.Baptist: Echoing verse 2, the text reaffirms that even in prison, 'the LORD was with Joseph.' God continues to show Joseph kindness ('hesed' - loyal love, mercy) and causes him to find favor with the chief jailer.
21.Catholic: Despite Joseph's unjust imprisonment, the narrative reiterates the key theme: 'the LORD was with Joseph.' God extends kindness ('hesed') to him and grants him favor in the sight of the prison keeper.
21.Methodist: Even in prison, the Lord is with Joseph, showing him kindness ('hesed') and giving him favor with the warden.
21.Lutheran: But the Lord was with Joseph and showed him steadfast love (hesed) and gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison.
21.Presbyterian: Reiterates God's faithfulness: the Lord remains with Joseph in prison, extending kindness ('hesed') and granting him favor with the warden.
21.Pentecostal: God is still with Joseph in prison, shows him kindness, gives him favor with the warden.
21.Episcopalian/Anglican: Even in prison, the Lord is with Joseph, showing him kindness (steadfast love) and granting him favor with the prison warden.
21.Orthodox: Crucially, even within the confines of the prison, 'the LORD was with Joseph.' God demonstrates steadfast love ('hesed') towards him and ensures he finds favor with the prison administrator.
21.Other: But while Joseph was there in the prison, the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
21.Prefer not to say: But while Joseph was there in the prison, the Lord was with him; he showed him kindness and granted him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.

22.General: So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.
22.Non-Denominational: So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.
22.Baptist: Mirroring his rise in Potiphar's house, Joseph gains the warden's trust due to God's favor. The warden delegates responsibility to Joseph, putting him in charge of all the other prisoners and the prison's operations.
22.Catholic: Due to the favor granted by God, the prison keeper entrusts Joseph with authority over all the other prisoners and makes him responsible for managing all the activities within the prison.
22.Methodist: The warden puts Joseph in charge of all the prisoners and everything done in the prison.
22.Lutheran: The keeper of the prison put Joseph in charge of all the prisoners who were in the prison. Whatever was done there, he was the one who did it.
22.Presbyterian: Reflecting his earlier success, Joseph earns the warden's trust and is given charge over the other prisoners and prison activities.
22.Pentecostal: Warden puts Joseph in charge of all prisoners and prison work.
22.Episcopalian/Anglican: The warden entrusts Joseph with responsibility for all the prisoners and all the work done in the prison.
22.Orthodox: Consequently, the prison keeper delegates authority to Joseph, placing him in charge of all fellow inmates and the overall administration of the prison.
22.Other: So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.
22.Prefer not to say: So the warden put Joseph in charge of all those held in the prison, and he was made responsible for all that was done there.

23.General: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
23.Non-Denominational: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
23.Baptist: Similar to Potiphar, the warden develops complete trust in Joseph, not needing to supervise his work. The reason is explicitly stated again: 'because the LORD was with him. And whatever he did, the LORD made it succeed.' This concludes the chapter, emphasizing God's sovereign hand in Joseph's life despite adversity.
23.Catholic: The prison keeper delegates full authority to Joseph, not needing to oversee anything under Joseph's charge. The narrative explicitly attributes this trust and Joseph's success to the fact that 'the LORD was with him' and granted success to all his efforts.
23.Methodist: The warden trusts Joseph completely, paying no attention to details under Joseph's care. The reason is restated: the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success.
23.Lutheran: The keeper of the prison paid no attention to anything that was in Joseph's charge, because the Lord was with him. And whatever he did, the Lord made it succeed.
23.Presbyterian: The warden fully trusts Joseph's management, relieving himself of oversight. The ultimate reason is reiterated: the Lord was with Joseph, ensuring his success.
23.Pentecostal: Warden didn't supervise Joseph because God was with Joseph, making him successful.
23.Episcopalian/Anglican: The warden pays no attention to anything under Joseph's care because the Lord is with Joseph, granting him success in all he does.
23.Orthodox: The prison administrator relies entirely on Joseph, relinquishing oversight. The text concludes by reaffirming the foundational reason: 'the LORD was with him' and ensured the success of all his endeavors.
23.Other: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
23.Prefer not to say: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care, because the Lord was with Joseph and gave him success in whatever he did.
